head.title: Famous Dinosaur Gets Her Own Web Pages

identified-content.classifier: Top/Classifieds/Job Market/Job Categories/Technology, Telecommunications and Internet

hedline.hl1: Famous Dinosaur Gets Her Own Web Pages

abstract.p: Sue, world's largest, best-preserved Tyrannosaurus rex, has her own Web pages, part of Web site of Field Museum in Chicago, where Sue makes her home; site described; photo (M)

block.p: Sue, the world's largest, best-preserved Tyrannosaurus rex, is also the world's largest, best-preserved T. rex to have her own Web pages (www.fmnh.org/sue), part of the Web site of the Field Museum in Chicago, where Sue makes her home. The site features photographs; information on Sue, a 42-foot-long dinosaur; and a chronology of her modern life, from her discovery by Susan Hendrikson in 1990 to her preservation and eventual purchase by the museum in 1997.
Browser A selection of events and sites on the Web.

TODAY and TOMORROW, starting at 5 p.m.; SATURDAY, starting at 1 p.m. www.jazzfest2000.com The 6th annual Downtown JazzFest from City Hall Park in New York, featuring Herbie Hancock, Branford Marsalis, David Sanchez, Leo Gandelman and Carla Cook.
TODAY and TOMORROW, 8 p.m. www.sportingarena.com A broadcast of the last two nights in a chat series on sportsmanship, with athletes and coaches from professional sports teams.
FRIDAY, 4 p.m. chat.msn.com/msnlive/features/nursebetty.asp Chat with the actor Morgan Freeman about the new comedy ''Nurse Betty.'' Greg Kinnear will be in a chat on Sunday at 2:30 p.m.
MONDAY through SEPT. 1, 10 a.m. www.usanetwork.com Daily audio broadcast, with a look at the day's matchups and questions from tennis fans, at the United States Open Championships.

Sue, the world's largest, best-preserved Tyrannosaurus rex, is also the world's largest, best-preserved T. rex to have her own Web pages (www.fmnh.org/sue), part of the Web site of the Field Museum in Chicago, where Sue makes her home. The site features photographs; information on Sue, a 42-foot-long dinosaur; and a chronology of her modern life, from her discovery by Susan Hendrikson in 1990 to her preservation and eventual purchase by the museum in 1997.
